node.title: Two spotted hyenas at the Denver Zoo are the first known to have Covid-19.
node.alt: Ngozi, 22, is one of two hyenas at the Denver Zoo among the first in the world to have tested positive for the coronavirus, according to officials.
node.description: The adult hyenas, who tested positive for the coronavirus, have so far exhibited mild symptoms of Covid, but they are believed to be “in good shape and improving,” a zoo spokesman said.
node.content: ["Two spotted hyenas at the Denver Zoo have tested positive for the coronavirus, becoming the first known cases in the world among hyenas, zoo and veterinary services officials announced on Friday.", "The adult hyenas, 22-year-old Ngozi and 23-year-old Kibo, have so far exhibited mild symptoms of Covid, including \u201ca little bit of coughing and sneezing,\u201d and nasal discharge and lethargy, but they are believed to be \u201cin good shape and improving,\u201d Jake Kubi\u00e9, a spokesman for the Denver Zoo, said on Saturday.", "The hyenas are the latest in a number of infections confirmed among animals at the Denver Zoo, with positive test results returned for 11 lions and two tigers, which Mr. Kubi\u00e9 said \u201chave either fully recovered or are on their way to recovery.\u201d", "Samples were collected from a variety of species at the zoo, said the announcement from the National Veterinary Services Laboratories, which is part of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The samples were tested by the Colorado State University Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory.", "Coronavirus infections among animals in zoos and sanctuaries have affected several types of big cats, otters and nonhuman primates, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The risk of these animals spreading the virus to people is considered to be low, the C.D.C. says.", "Early in the pandemic, a Malayan tiger that was 4 years old at the time was the first tiger to test positive for the virus at the Bronx Zoo. Other cases among zoo animals followed there and elsewhere. Recently, coronavirus infections were detected among tigers and lions at the National Zoo in Washington, where a lion was reported to have the Delta variant; Sumatran tigers and snow leopards at a children\u2019s zoo in Lincoln, Neb.; the world\u2019s oldest gorilla in captivity among others at the zoo in Atlanta; and even among vaccinated tigers at the San Diego Zoo.", "This summer, zoo animals started receiving an experimental Covid vaccine made by Zoetis, a veterinary pharmaceutical company in New Jersey.", "Ngozi and Kibo, older adults in hyena years, were not vaccinated, and neither were the tigers or lions found to have been infected in Denver, but the zoo is working to prioritize its supply of the animal Covid vaccine and ordering more. \u201cWe have been able to vaccinate some of our animals, primates and great apes, because we know they are most at risk, but we haven\u2019t had the supply to vaccinate all of our other animals,\u201d Mr. Kubi\u00e9 said.", "For now, Mr. Kubi\u00e9 said, the zoo\u2019s staff is observing infected animals for any signs of worsening health, whether they are less active or lose their appetite, to administer antiviral or anti-nausea medication if needed."]
